instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.5V_S5: What is 5V_S5? 5V_S5 is an abbreviation for “PP5V_S5” which is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 state. .
definitions.5V_S3: What is 5V_S3? 5V_S3 is an abbreviation of “PP5V_S3” which is a 5 volt power rail present in an S3 state. S3 (Suspend to RAM) is a state where the system saves its context to RAM, a faster but more power-consuming method than S4. The system shuts down most components except for RAM, which remains powered to retain the system state. PM_SLP_S4_L is required for this rail to be present. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green Light no Power
threads.message:
3115 board with no liquid damage, only thing that looks funny is a tad bit of corrosion on a BKLT capacitor (<CAPACITOR>C9712</CAPACITOR>)

Pulsing PPVRTC, pulsing <SIGNAL>5V_S5</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>, no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> or <SIGNAL>3V3_S3</SIGNAL>.
CPUVcore is at 0.

<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> pulses around 20 mV so I don't think it's turning on enough for the SMC to do much.

MoBo is power cycling right? Probably a short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>? Is this a rabbit hole board with no clear end?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green Light no Power
threads.message: Found a short on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>, inject 5v see what happens?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green Light no Power
threads.message: You did check that without power and waited long enough for it to discharge? What is resistance to GND on <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green Light no Power
threads.message:
GND to <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> is .1 ohm
Yes, without power, checked again today without having powered on.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green Light no Power
threads.message: Inject voltage, the short is low enough that something should heat up. Start low and monitor current.
